awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Run-Time Hardware-Assisted Malware Detection Using Machine Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Malware, a broad term for any type of malicious software, is a piece of code designed by cyber attackers to infect computing systems without the user consent, typically for harmful purposes such as stealing sensitive information. The ubiquity of information technology has made malware a serious threat. Detecting malware in a system is a difficult task, particularly when the malware is stealthy. Hardware-assisted malware detection (HMD) mechanisms seek runtime detection of malware. However, several challenges exist with deployment of HMD including limited availability of hardware registers, diversity of microarchitectural events, and difficulty of anomalous behavior detection for stealthy malware. Proposed research aims to find lightweight HMDs that are not too costly to implement and provide continuous runtime monitoring.

The core research agenda is development of lightweight malware detection mechanisms using low level microarchitectural behavior. Specifically, this project is interested in (i) developing effective machine-learning classifier against malware that are relatively inexpensive to implement; and (ii) development of tools and methods for evaluating effectiveness and robustness of various solution alternatives.

From a societal viewpoint, this work enhances the research, education, and diversity at University of California Davis (UCD) by involving graduate, undergraduate, minority and female students, and enriches several courses that are offered at UCD. The proposed research effort could inspire and enable new approaches to securing computer systems, in particular in emerging domains such as Internet-of-Things (IoT), where computational requirement is constrained. Research results will be integrated in graduate and undergraduate courses offered by the investigator.

The proposed solutions will be freely shared and broadly disseminated through public portals, https://ece.gmu.edu/~hhomayou/publications.html and GitHub: https://github.com/ASEEC/ML_classifier and https://github.com/ASEEC/HPC_Trace.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Summary 

 

Cyber threats are becoming smarter and harder to catch. Many traditional security tools rely on known patterns to detect malware, but newer, more advanced attacks—called “zero-day” attacks—don’t follow known patterns and often go undetected. This project focused on creating next-generation security tools that can spot these new types of malware in real time, using the computer's hardware itself as a source of information.

 

What We Did

We developed a new system that uses machine learning to detect suspicious activity by analyzing signals from a computer’s processor, known as hardware performance counters (HPCs). These signals provide insight into how programs behave and can reveal patterns that suggest something malicious is happening—even if the threat is brand new.

 

Some of our key achievements include:

 

  • High accuracy detection: We built a smart system that uses reinforcement learning to automatically choose the best detection method depending on the situation. It reached 96% accuracy in spotting zero-day malware using a small and efficient set of hardware signals.
  •  Efficiency and speed: Our tools work even on devices with limited computing power. One version, called Adaptive-HMD, achieved nearly 94% accuracy while using five times less computing resources than traditional methods.
  •  Smarter feature selection: We developed a new way to pick the most useful signals from the processor, helping our system stay both accurate and efficient.
  •  Real-world performance: We tested the system in different parts of the operating system and found that running it in the system’s core (kernel space) leads to faster and more efficient operation.
  •  Robust protection: Another version of the system, called SCARF, achieved near 100% detection accuracy with zero false alarms in detecting side channel attacks.
  •  Lightweight success: We showed that even simple models using just 2–4 hardware signals can perform nearly as well as models using 16 signals—especially when enhanced with smarter learning techniques like AdaBoost and Bagging.

 

To evaluate our methods, we used well-known analysis techniques such as ROC (Receiver Operating Characteristic) curves and AUC (Area Under the Curve) scores. Some models achieved AUC scores above 0.93, which shows strong reliability and confidence in their performance.

 

Why It Matters

Beyond the technical results, this project had several broader impacts:

 

  • Training the next generation: Several Ph.D. students involved in this work completed their degrees and began academic careers. A postdoctoral researcher also transitioned into a faculty role, contributing to education and research in cybersecurity.
  •  Sharing with the world: We published our findings in top conferences and made our data and code publicly available on GitHub to help other researchers and developers build upon our work.
  •  Bringing research into the classroom: Insights and techniques from this project were incorporated into a graduate-level machine learning course, helping educate over 100 students in how AI can be used to secure modern systems.
